segments.text: Samuel Montoya, self-employed mechanic, Bryan, Texas, approximately 61 years old, interviewed May 3, 1975, by Adela Lopez and Jim Crisp.
He lost his father, and then his mother and his brothers came into Floresville.
And from Floresville, they had a hard time.
So they heard about having, down in Southeast Texas, having a big saw mill there.
So they hit the saw mills.
When they hit the saw mills, well then, they found a way out.
And my father was lucky.
He was a blacksmith by trade.
And he was a, what do you call this?
Flatheads.
Do you know what a flathead is?
I don't know what a flathead is.
It's one of these big worms, white worms that grow in trees.
They feed in the trees.
They call them flatheads.
He saw logs.
They call them flatheads.
Log sawyers.
He saw logs for many years.
He built a sawmill in
Brandcroft, Texas.
That's about 10 miles, maybe 15 miles from Orange, Texas, in Orange County.
And then from there, he moved to Texla back in 1923.
I remember from there, I owned real good then, because in 1923, I was chasing rabbits, squirrels, all that.
And I was big enough to do that and get lost.
Spend a night in the woods and find my way back next day by the sun.
And well, I finally grew up, went to school.
I went to school at the age of nine.
And I started naturally with the little ones.
And I was a giant for the little ones.
But I learned to read and write.
And I finished my years in school in sixth grade.
Well, I did finish sixth grade, though.
I graduated from sixth grade.
Or which awaited one.
And then from there, it was back in 1932, we lived in Deweyville.
And that place still stands.
It's a pretty little town.
It's getting to be a good little business there.
I have a few friends there yet that we went to school together.
And 32, we hit Brian.
Well, my uncle was a mechanic here for the Missouri Pacific.
And he kept up to that steam engine there.
And he wrote to me in that year, asking me to come to Brian and visit him.
So by that time, sawmill had played out.
So we didn't have a job.
My daddy didn't have a job.
And we was looking for a way out.
When this car comes in, I had me a Model T that I bought back in 28.
And that's where I learned my automobile trade.
When I was going to school, there was a man by the name of, well, Shannon.
And he was an engineer there for the sawmill that he built.
these engines, these locomotives.
And he started building one.
And I asked him, Shannon, what are you going to do here?
He says, I'm going to build me a locomotive.
Wow, I'd like to see that.
He says, well, we're going to build it from the rail up.
And you can see it every day.
You may come by and see what progress we have.
So there were two men working.
But he was the head engineer.
I got to see that engine, get out of that shop, and I got to maneuver the thing.
I was big enough.
The only thing was that I wasn't strong enough to pull that big lever.
That was pretty heavy to do.
But when I did, I got pretty smart and found ways to do it with a club.
And I moved that engine.
I stopped it.
Then I got a little bigger.
That other little engine that was smaller than that, that was pretty easy to move.
It was half worn out.
That really was easy.
But I managed to learn how to move a locomotive real good and all that.
And then that was back in 28, 29.
Then we moved from Texas to Deauville.
That's when we came to Bryan.
When I came to Bryan, my uncle was
taking care of this big locomotive.
It was 900 horses in it.
Of course, to compare a mobile nowadays, that engine wasn't very big.
But it still was a big thing.
But my cousin said, Sam, I'm going to show you how to operate this engine.
I said, well, I learned a few days ago that a man's going to put things together.
You do it first.
And then you read the instructions before you made a mistake.
He said, you're doing it backwards.
I said, that's what I want to tell you.
Let me see if I do it backwards here.
He said, no, no, no, because this thing might get away from you.
I said, oh, what?
What so?
The engineer here with me can always stop it.
Oh, he felt big then.
I said, well, now, first thing, we pull this lever here back to make it back up.
And we pull the throttle a little at a time so it won't spin.
And you stop it, you pull this lever here, and it stopped it.
Hydraulics.
Oh, you don't know that?
Well, I'm an old man, you know.
I was about 18, 17, 18 then.
I said, well, I'll show you that.
I got around.
I said, well, I do know this.
By that, in a way, I know more than this.
being a Chevrolet or Ford, I don't care where he breaks down or where he stops, I'll get that thing going right there.
Now I know that.
He said, well, you learned that.
Well, I tell you, old days.
Well, he was very surprised, because I did.
Drive my car there and
And every time we have a little problem with it, I fix it.
What's going on?
Well, from then on, he didn't have a thing to say to me.
I said, another thing, I would like to make a boat since we have the river here pretty close.
I can make a boat out of some light lumber and let's go fishing.
I like fishing.
Oh, no.
I can't do it.
Oh, well.
So by that time, uh,
We had been here about, oh, I'd say 18 days, and the cotton field opened up for shopping cotton.
I never did know what a cotton field was, so I took my hoe, and we went with a bunch to Dr. Richardson's farm.
We went there to that farm, and
We started chopping cotton for the whole day, from sunup to sundown.
We chopped cotton for that season.
And then when the cotton harvest came in, we went cotton picking.
But I didn't have cotton picking hands.
It so happened that we went to the chancellor's place to pick cotton.
I tried my best to, and cotton was just right.
I mean, right size and plenty of it and all that.
But my cotton picking hands weren't there.
Forget it.
Told my dad, I was making, I was pulling 50 pounds of cotton a day from sunup to sundown.
I couldn't see anymore.
I said, this is going to kill me and store me to death.
I better move.
I said, I think I'm going to find a job and go write somewhere in Bryant.
So I left.
I said, I'll be back for you all Saturday morning.
So I came to Brian.
And just lucky that day, that Tuesday morning, I went down the street.
Saw this wrecking yard right there by 23rd and Brian.
I said, there's a wrecking yard.
I'm going to see if I can find it.
I went in there, inquired about the man's name.
I said, Mr. Brogdon?
Yes, sir.
I'm looking for a job.
Oh, a lot of people are looking for a job now.
Well, there's a lot of cotton back in the field.
What are you looking for?
Well, what are you?
I said, I just come from there.
I don't have cotton picking hands.
He said, well, what can you do?
I said, I can repair automobiles.
Oh, you look mighty young to know anything about that.
I said, well, just try me out.
He said, well, I'll tell you what I'll do.
I'll give you $3 a week.
I said, that's good enough.
That bit's cotton fake.
And I went to work for him for $3 a week.
But I enjoyed myself in that sense.
Really, the thing was that I didn't care about how much money I made.
The thing was that experiencing other automobiles, like the Moon, like the Whippet, like the Star, you name them, they were there.
I was working on them and fixing tires.
He had a sign there.
He said, you bust them, we fix them.
And we fixed batteries.
I learned how to rebuild a battery.
In fact, I built one that I put in.
But then he had a good Chevrolet there that I traded my Ford for and gave him $25 a boot.
And that Chevrolet didn't have a battery.
I said, it was broken.
I'm going to make me a battery and put it in my car.
He said, yeah, go on, do it.
So I built me a battery.
And I drove that car five years.
And when I sold the car, the battery wasn't in that car yet.
I said, I must have been a good battery manufacturer.
And I was surprised at that battery.
So I had good luck with it.
And then in 33, I joined the CC camp.
I thought I knew enough in automobiles to go to the CC camp.
get some other kind of experience, so I was took, I tell you.
Well, then we got in with this bunch of boys here in Bryan.
We went to, they took us to Arizona, Alpine.
And there we were, well, I went to a lot of places there after, like, for instance, Saturday and Sunday that we didn't work.
Flagstaff and Holbrook and
Other little places and rivers.
Imagine all that fish in those rivers and I can't go.
And those days I'd go, that's a lot of fish there.
Why do that?
You care too much about fishing.
It's better because I want to move around.
I thought if I sit down and fish, I'd lose time.
I'd be traveling while I had the opportunity.
So I kept going, kept going.
Well, in July of 33, I came back to Bryant.
I didn't like Bryant.
But I didn't have a choice.
I had to go to work in A&M College at Mass Hall to make a living.
I done had all the traveling.
I was tired of traveling.
And I almost held out for a while and rest.
And, well, what else I might think of?
So I worked there at the mess hall one session, which it was.
Well, I don't know if it was one session or what, but I went in there right after I got back in July.
And I worked there till January the next year.
That was 34.
In 34, I went to Houston.
I couldn't find a job in Houston, so I come back.
I spent about a month there in Houston, come back.
Couldn't make it.
Then I went to work back again there.
And I worked that spring there.
And it was in September I went back to Houston.
That was in 34.
Got me a job at the Wright Hotel serving tables there.
I took it up.
Wasn't making very much, but making my expenses and living.
having a lot of fun.
And I didn't care about nothing else but having a lot of fun.
And I did enjoy my work.
I don't know why.
Everywhere that I went to work that they treated me halfway right, I enjoyed my work.
Where I wasn't treated too good, I'd left it.
Never was afraid to leave a job.
I knew I had another one somewhere else.
And I'm still that way.
Of course, here, I've been here 30 years, and I can't leave it.
I have left it.
I left it, I think, was four times to go help out somewhere, whatever they call me.
I'd go there and say, let's call that a vacation.
I had a two-month, no, no, one-month vacation in Toledo, Ohio, back in 1948.
Closed up here and went to Toledo to work.
Fifteen days later, I came to my family.
We went out there.
We couldn't live.
Now let's go back home.
We come back home, open up my doors, and going back to work.
You just couldn't leave Brian, could you?
No, I tried my best.
I have my shoes tied here so tight that I can't leave.
Well, I decided I'll stay home.
But back in 1955, I was called from...
Teddy Decker in Houston to go keep up his equipment.
He had a nice shop and all that.
He gave me a good break.
Well, I went to work for him.
I worked for him nine months.
I couldn't make, I don't know why, making, I was making as much as I was, maybe a little more than I was making here, and I couldn't make ends meet.
See, there's something wrong here somewhere because I know it's,
It's about $35 more than I make at the shop.
And yet, I get my gas and my oil out of the company to go to Brian and back, and yet I can't make it.
And I wasn't paying board and room because I was living with a couple that were from Brian, and they wouldn't charge me a dime to live with them.
I tried to pay them.
I said, no, as long as you're here, you
So you get settled.
I said, heck, it might be two, three years before I get settled.
He said, you got a home here?
So I said, goodness, and yet I can't make Ian Smith.
So I tell the old man, quit?
Oh, you can't quit now.
Yes, I can.
He said, well, I tell you, I'm going to let you go as soon as you find me a man like you.
I said, oh, man, I'm going to find you one better than I.
He said, well, just one like you, not any better.
Well, turning in the papers, advertised for a man that would take care of equipment, a maintenance man, experienced.
One of the first day I had about 50 there to interview.
I said, oh, I can't interview all of those.
I told the old man, I said, come down here.
He said, that's your job.
I said, you're going to find the man.
The thing was that he wanted to tie me
I was already tied down where I couldn't get away from there, and he was going to keep me there.
Said, Mr. Manley, I have so much work to do that I can't interview you.
He said, well, you let the work go, you interview the people.
You call them, now you get into them.
Well, I tried to call the youngest ones, someone that looked to me like I had common sense.
Well, I found several of them.
I told the restaurant, well, I'll call you.
They gave me all the address, all the phone numbers, and a book full of address, and telephone number, and names, and all kinds.
I'll call you as soon as the old man decides.
I can't hire you, but I will recommend the man that I think is good for the job.
And the old man, oh, I say he's around 70.
He want to beat me up because I wouldn't give him the job.
Look, I need a young man.
You're a retired man.
He said, no, I'm not.
I said, well, that's your hard luck.
And he almost beat me up.
But I said, no, come on.
Come on.
Go on.
You know you can't quit me.
If you could, I'd let you.
But I've got some work to do.
I can't lose that kind of a time.
But he really was mad.
So then after three weeks of fighting, fighting the boss man, I told one young man, now you're going to stay here and you just take over.
I'm going home.
And I did.
And I don't know, I believe it was six months later, Mr. Mandler came to the shop here.
And he, him and Mr. Lindsay, that neighbor there, you put them together, you think,
You wouldn't know who was Mr. Manley.
And I was working under a car.
I said, how are you doing?
I thought I recognized you.
Oh, I'm doing all right.
Well, when you get through there or you want to take a little break, let's go get some coffee.
All right.
So I get out and
Oh, how you doing?
Oh, just fine, let's see.
But I thought it was Mr. Lindsey.
Never did think of Mr. Manley anymore, so we talked and said a lot of things.
After a while he said, you know, you don't know who I am.
I said, I see you every day.
He said, oh, now I know you don't know who I am.
Yes, I do.
You're Mr. Lindsey, aren't you?
No.
But you know that mostly every Monday we came in your house there and drank some coffee, chatted, you know.
Oh, boy.
Well, who are you thinking?
I'm sorry.
Oh, never be.
Never be sorry.
Let's go get some coffee.
Came in here.
Sit there like we did every Monday.
I was off on Monday.
And he'd come here to drink coffee with me and spend an hour or two with me.
And then he'd go back.
Well, we'd sit there and say, I don't want you to go to work, but I want you to do one thing.
The 1st of October, I want you to come over to my office and spend an hour or two with me.
I have something for you there.
I'm retiring.
I'm leaving that day, and I want you to come there.
But one day, I was working in the shop there, and I had so much to do.
I had six trucks to put up with.
Besides that, I had some machinery in the plant that I had to work over.
It looked like that week I was a little behind.
He called me.
He said, come over to the office.
I need you right now.
So I didn't think of pulling my dirty clothes off.
I just washed my hands, kept my grace of heart.
Went up to his office.
There's all these big wheels there.
I went to take my hand.
Oh, I felt like I wanted to go in the floor.
This was here in Brad?
No, no, that was in Houston, yes.
And it says, now, this is a big Brad from Chicago.
Now, I call you because I want them to know you.
They already know it by your name and what you do and all that.
But I said, when you tell me this, dirty or clean or whatever, you're the same man.
You're not going to change any.
You're right about that.
Yeah, we've got a chair, a tie, and whatnot.
There's nobody.
We're just partners in this same job.
And you know, I appreciated all of that, because you may not have an education.
Oh, boy, those big engineers and all that.
It made me feel mighty small.
But after they say, no, no, we're all the same.
We're in the same business.
We've got your department.
We have ours.
Each one of us has.
We have to do one job to get this thing going.
That's right.
So then I said,
You'll have to pardon me because I have so much to do and I got to get it done.
I said, no, we're going to eat.
Oh, no.
I said, yes.
I said, we're going to eat.
I said, wait a minute.
Give me about five minutes.
Let me go pull this.
He said, okay, okay.
I went down there and pulled my cover all up, white stuff.
Then we went to eat.
They took me to, I don't know what place it was.
Beautiful place.
I mean, I
I couldn't hardly sit on the chairs.
I felt so small.
But they fed me.
And they'd talk all day.
And I kept saying, I got some tomorrow.
I don't know what they had.
I never did learn why they called me.
They want to talk to me and all that.
But later on, when Mr. Manley came here and said that he wanted me to go to
and be in his office on the 31st of October, I didn't go.
And then two or three weeks later, a ball blittered in my head.
I said, golly, I bet you I missed the biggest opportunity of my life there.
Well, that wasn't the first one, anyway.
I lost many.
They never treated you like that around here, though.
I invented apparatus back in 1941, 42.
And I was expecting to find an automobile, waiting for an automobile of that model that I invented an apparatus for to hit the junkyard so I could buy it to make it work.
And I patented the thing.
Well, I waited and waited three years.
And one day, there was a thing.
I looked at it.
Uh-oh.
Something going wrong now.
Came to the garage and took my piece.
I said, Davis, this here, see what I... How do you copy that?
I said, no.
I made this three years ago to go on this 40 miles here already.
And here you have one already.
What are you telling me?
It just came out.
This is a new patent.
I said, well, three years ago I made this thing.
But I didn't patent it because I wasn't sure if it was going to work or not.
But look.
They said, well, you just lost about $10,000 plus commission.
And I said, well, that's part of my living.
That's all right.
I don't want to get to race anyway.
Live.
The car don't kill me.
I'm going to live until I die.
That's the beginning of it.
Oh, we still have how much?
No telling.
Well, back in the war years, I was called to Bryan to come and that Bryan, what was the fourth place name then?
Bryan Motor Company.
By Mr. Elvin Depot.

by the way i was working in huntsville at that time at the cheryl lake place and i was called down here fourth place i came here i said well uh miss depot the only way i could move is that see i don't want to go in there or in the service because i know i'm gonna be put in the navy and i don't like to be in there in the boat because i'm gonna go in there

bottom of the boat now i don't mind going being on top but being on the bottom and i know where i'm going because i'm a mechanic in the first place and that's where i'm gonna go now i don't want to be there they say oh don't you worry about that if you work with us we'll we'll see that you don't go good move and i think that's when i i said well since i'm not going in the service i'm gonna build my house i built this house
by myself.
It's made out of concrete blocks that are 14 inches long, 12 inches high, and 12 inches wide.
Each block weighs around 70 pounds.
Sturdy place.
Yes.
I made 1,500 blocks.
My foundation is seven feet deep down to hard.
There's a rock seven feet deep here that the railroad pick, it'll bounce.
It won't go through.
That's where this house is sitting on, on that kind of a rock.
What year did you build your house?
I built it in 46.
And built from...
Later on, I'll put that top corner, that additional thing here.
Two or three years ago, I had that back built.
I didn't have time to build it.
I did all the inside in that one down there.
I just made the whole thing.
But I wired this.
Pretty good electrician.
They stand up that many years, and mine must be pretty good.
Sewer lines, I never put in my own sewer lines.
And I never had one plug yet for many years.
My house, that train, that steam engine, when we had the steam engines here and they're coming through there, every time it pumped, this thing would shake.
Now that's how hard, how deep they found it on the railroad.
But I could feel the engine.
And all the windows were made out of wood and, you know, wood frame.
And later on, I put this long windows in.
But they would shake.
And this house never break.
They don't have a broken spot where I had to patch and I like that.
I think I built, I wasn't too good of a doubler then.
I'm a better, a little better now, but.
I think I was about 30 years old then.
No, I was younger.
Well, I'd say around 30 anyway.
I said, I must have a lot of sins.
I know men right now that are 45 and they don't have sins at all yet.
I don't know where I got them from, but I give myself a lot of polish.
But my son, my son Sammy, when I said, Sammy, you're going to
graduate from high school.
I want you to go to college.
Not that I don't think you're smart, no.
But on top of that, I want you to be smarter yet.
So he went to college.
And he says the first year he was in college, he learned how smart I was.
I said, well, good thing I didn't have school.
Otherwise, I don't know what I'd be.
Would have ruined you probably.
Wow, I've been in penitentiary, yeah, behind bars.
I've been, oh, probably been...
